required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparative A1 vs A2 Formula and Breast Feeding on Alimentation and Gastrointestinal Digestion for the Infant
clinical_study.official_title: Comparative Effects of A1 Versus A2®Cow Milk Based Formula and Breast Feeding on Alimentation and Gastrointestinal Digestion for the Infant: a Pilot Double-blinded, Randomized, Controlled Parallel Study

brief_summary.textblock: This pilot study primarily aimed to compare effects of breast feeding, A1 versus A2®cow milk based formula on alimentation and gastrointestinal digestion. The impact of the study products on fecal myeloperoxidase (MPO), short-chain fatty acid (SCFA), secretory immunoglobulin A (sIgA) concentration, gastrointestinal tolerance, defecating habit and infant growth were also evaluated.

primary_outcome.description: Change from Baseline weekly average of the number of defecation per day at 8 weeks

secondary_outcome.description: Weekly average score of stool consistency
Weekly average score of stool color

secondary_outcome.measure: Fecal Short Chain Fatty Acid (SCFA) concentration
secondary_outcome.description: Acetic Acid , Propanoic Acid, Butanoic Acid, Total SCFA
Weekly average of cry frequency per day
Weekly average of cumulative cry duration per day
Weekly average of cumulative sleep duration per day
Weekly average of milk regurgitation frequency per day

arm_group.description: Oral consumption of Nutricia Aptamil Stage 1 formula (traditional cow milk)
Oral consumption of a2® Platinum Stage 1 formula (containing 100% A2® beta -casein)

intervention.intervention_name: Oral consumption of Nutricia Aptamil Stage 1 formula
intervention.description: Daily oral consumption of Nutricia Aptamil Stage 1 formula

intervention.intervention_name: Oral consumption of a2® Platinum Stage 1 formula
intervention.description: Daily oral consumption of a2® Platinum Stage 1 formula
Daily oral consumption of breast milk
